slug: /179
title: "This Week In React #179: useActionState, Redwood, Waku, Astro, Pre-rendering, Bun, Kotekan, memo, Radix, shadcn/ui, React-Navigation, RN-Screens, CodePush, VisionOS, TypeScript, Node.js..."

segments.source_content: Hi everyone!

segments.source_content: Another week full of interesting news! I found many links, and saved a few of them for next week, which should be a quiet one due to Easter Monday.

translations.fr: Une autre semaine riche en actualitÃ©s passionnantes ! J'ai collectÃ© de nombreux liens et en ai rÃ©servÃ© quelques-uns pour la semaine prochaine, qui devrait Ãªtre plus calme avec le lundi de PÃ¢ques.

segments.source_content: It's exciting to see Waku and Redwood becoming stronger meta-frameworks, and new innovative experiments built on top of Bun such as Kotekan and a pre-rendering macro.

segments.source_content: React Native also has interesting updates, notably a React Navigation v7 sneak peek, and a nice React Native Screen upgrade.

segments.source_content: I was at [React.paris](https://react.paris/) last week. It was a really great conf, and it was nice to meet some of you! It's great that Paris is finally back in the React conf game.

segments.source_content: The party is not over, because next month we also have [React Connection](https://reactconnection.io/) and [React Native Connection](https://reactnativeconnection.io/) on 22-23 April in Paris! The newsletter is once again a conf media partner. You can get a [-20% discount](https://www.billetweb.fr/react-connection-2024?discount=TWIR) with the code "TWIR", and we'll run a ticket giveaway on Twitter this Friday.

segments.source_content: With 23k stars and 500,000 daily users, react-admin is the framework of choice for single-page applications (ERPs, Admins, B2B apps). Compatible with Vite, Next, and Remix, it builds upon acclaimed libraries like react-hook-form, react-query, react-router and material-ui to accelerate your development game.

Compatible avec Vite, Next et Remix, il s'appuie sur des bibliothÃ¨ques reconnues comme react-hook-form, react-query, react-router et material-ui pour accÃ©lÃ©rer votre dÃ©veloppement.

Compatible avec Vite, Next et Remix, il s'appuie sur des bibliothÃ¨ques renommÃ©es comme react-hook-form, react-query, react-router et material-ui pour accÃ©lÃ©rer votre dÃ©veloppement.

translations.en: [**Les composants serveur React dÃ©sormais dans RedwoodJS**](https://redwoodjs.com/blog/rsc-now-in-redwoodjs)

segments.source_content: Bighorn, the next Redwood â€œepochâ€ starting at v8.0, will bet all-in on React Server Components. This article explains why Redwood now prefers RSCs over GraphQL, which wasnâ€™t the best DX to get started with for most devs and projects. GraphQL will remain supported and can be used alongside RSCs in the same app. Redwood Cells now allow you to export a new â€œdataâ€ function to load the Cell data.

translations.fr: Bighorn, la prochaine "Ã©poque" de Redwood dÃ©marrant en v8.0, misera entiÃ¨rement sur les composants serveur React (RSC). Cet article explique pourquoi Redwood prÃ©fÃ¨re dÃ©sormais les RSC Ã  GraphQL, qui n'offrait pas la meilleure expÃ©rience dÃ©veloppeur (DX) initiale pour la plupart des dÃ©veloppeurs et projets. GraphQL restera pris en charge et pourra Ãªtre utilisÃ© conjointement aux RSC dans la mÃªme application. Les Cellules Redwood permettent dÃ©sormais d'exporter une nouvelle fonction "data" pour charger les donnÃ©es de la cellule.
translations.en: Bighorn, la prochaine "Ã¨re" de Redwood dÃ©marrant en v8.0, misera entiÃ¨rement sur les composants serveur React (RSC). Cet article explique pourquoi Redwood prÃ©fÃ¨re dÃ©sormais les RSC Ã  GraphQL, qui n'offrait pas la meilleure expÃ©rience dÃ©veloppeur (DX) pour dÃ©marrer la plupart des projets. GraphQL restera pris en charge et pourra Ãªtre utilisÃ© conjointement avec les RSC. Les Cellules Redwood permettent dÃ©sormais d'exporter une nouvelle fonction "data" pour charger les donnÃ©es de la cellule.

segments.source_content: You can try Redwood Bighorn today as a v8 canary release, but there are still many rough edges mentioned in the blog post, that theyâ€™ll fix before the official major release. Thereâ€™s another interesting article to read [comparing Redwood routing conventions to Next.js and Remix](https://redwoodjs.com/blog/whats-different-comparing-the-router-in-nextjs-app-api-nextjs-pages-api-remix-and-redwoodjs).

translations.fr: Vous pouvez essayer Redwood Bighorn aujourd'hui en version canari v8, mais il subsiste encore de nombreuses imperfections mentionnÃ©es dans l'article de blog, qu'ils corrigeront avant la sortie officielle majeure. Il y a un autre article intÃ©ressant Ã  lire [comparant les conventions de routage de Redwood Ã  Next.js et Remix](https://redwoodjs.com/blog/whats-different-comparing-the-router-in-nextjs-app-api-nextjs-pages-api-remix-and-redwoodjs).
translations.en: Vous pouvez essayer Redwood Bighorn dÃ¨s aujourd'hui en version canary v8, mais le billet de blog mentionne encore de nombreuses aspÃ©ritÃ©s qui seront corrigÃ©es avant la sortie officielle majeure. Un autre article intÃ©ressant Ã  lire [compare les conventions de routage de Redwood avec Next.js et Remix](https://redwoodjs.com/blog/whats-different-comparing-the-router-in-nextjs-app-api-nextjs-pages-api-remix-and-redwoodjs).

segments.source_content:
- ğŸ’¸ [React Universe Conf - We care about a diverse lineup, so we prolong our CFP until April 5. We encourage all women in tech to submit talks!](https://www.reactuniverseconf.com/?utm_campaign=React_Universe_Conf&utm_source=email&utm_content=This_Week_in_React)
- ğŸ‘€ [React Core PR - useActionState](https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/28491): The PR is now merged and has been added to the [canary changelog](https://github.com/facebook/react/blob/main/CHANGELOG-canary.md).
- ğŸ’¬ [Astro proposal - Form actions](https://github.com/withastro/roadmap/discussions/871): Astro is exploring options for form submissions and mutations to feed their new Astro DB product, taking into consideration React 19 islands using useActionState() and useFormStatus().
- ğŸ¦ [Sebastian Silbermann (React core team) joins Vercel](https://twitter.com/sebsilbermann/status/1772229730747490691)
- ğŸ“– [Remix new docs - CSS files](https://remix.run/docs/en/main/guides/css-files)
- ğŸ“œ [Power of Partial Prerendering with Bun](https://aralroca.com/blog/partial-prerendering): An interesting idea, using import attributes to pre-render React components thanks to a Bun macro.
- ğŸ“œ [A faster React.memo()](https://romgrk.com/posts/react-fast-memo/): Argues that React is using a generic shallowCompare function for React.memo() that could be greatly optimized by using a specialized comparison function that assumes the things to compare are React props.
- ğŸ“œ [What is a layout in React?](https://www.ericburel.tech/blog/what-layout-means-in-react): A good overview presenting how layouts are implemented differently in Remix, Next.js, or Astro.
- ğŸ“œ [Diving into the Node.js Website Redesign](https://nodejs.org/en/blog/announcements/diving-into-the-nodejs-website-redesign): Node.js just launched a new Next.js website and shares behind-the-scenes details. They considered Nextra but settled on a custom Next.js setup. The site is statically built, using ISR for dynamic content.
- ğŸ“œ [This Pattern Will Wreck Your React App's TS Performance](https://www.totaltypescript.com/react-apps-ts-performance): Matt recommends using â€œinterface extendsâ€ instead of â€œ&â€, drawing on the story of a Sentry TS perf issue.
- ğŸ“œ [Utilizing useOptimistic() across the component tree in Next.js](https://aurorascharff.no/posts/utilizing-useoptimistic-across-the-component-tree-in-nextjs/): Explains why and how to share the useOptimistic value through a React context.
- ğŸ“œ [Why I Like React (even in 2024)](https://ejosh.co/de/2024/03/why-i-like-react-even-in-2024/)
- ğŸ“œ [Building a Â«hold to confirmÂ» button with Framer Motion](https://sinja.io/blog/hold-to-confirm-button-react-framer-motion)
- ğŸ“œ [React useEffect and objects as dependency - 4 approaches to avoid unnecessary re-renders](https://profy.dev/article/react-useeffect-with-object-dependency)
- ğŸ“œ [React-Three-Fiber - Moebius-style post-processing and other stylized shaders](https://blog.maximeheckel.com/posts/moebius-style-post-processing/)
- ğŸ“œ [How to Build Your Own ChatGPT Clone Using Clerk & AWS Bedrock](https://conermurphy.com/blog/how-to-build-your-own-chatgpt-clone-using-clerk-aws-bedrock)
- ğŸ“œ [Exploring useSyncExternalStore, a lesser-known React Hook](https://blog.logrocket.com/exploring-usesyncexternalstore-react-hook/)
- ğŸ“œ [Remix Case Study - Shopify rebuilding Shop with Remix](https://remix.run/blog/shop-case-study)
- ğŸ“¦ [Waku 0.20 - Introducing â€œpages routerâ€](https://waku.gg/blog/introducing-pages-router): Waku continues to push toward becoming a first-class React meta-framework. The latest release adds a lightweight file-based router and the introduction article presents its conventions. You can choose between static or dynamic rendering on a per-page basis.
- ğŸ“¦ [Kotekan - A simple React framework built on Bun, supporting React Server Components](https://kotekan.dev/blog/introducing-kotekan): My co-author Benedikt created his own experimental meta-framework, supporting React Server Components. Unlike other frameworks trying to stay decoupled from a specific runtime, Kotekan leverages tight coupling with Bun for both bundling and runtime. It looks like other interesting things are not mentioned in the intro post, notably a mobile app demo using react-strict-dom and StyleX. Thatâ€™s impressive that the website is already built with it.
- ğŸ“¦ [Radix Themes 3.0](https://www.radix-ui.com/blog/themes-3): This new version adds custom color palettes, many new components, and a new layout engine.
- ğŸ“¦ [shadcn/ui update - Blocks](https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/changelog): Fully responsive, accessible, and composable ready-made components, starting with dashboard layouts and authentication pages.
- ğŸ“¦ [@vite-pwa/remix - Zero-config PWA Plugin for Remix](https://github.com/vite-pwa/remix)
- ğŸ“¦ [Remotion 4.0.130 - Lambda renders are now faster](https://www.remotion.dev/blog/faster-lambda)
- ğŸ¥ [Jack Herrington - Finally Fix Your Issues With JS/React Memory Leaks](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qERgb3pWfu0)
- ğŸ¥ [UI Engineering - Senior-Level Understanding of React Portals](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5F7GrlIPdJ4)
- ğŸ¥ [Theo - The End Of React Router](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nZKlPtQqqgQ)
- ğŸ¥ [James Quick - I Didn't Know Next.js Server Actions Could Do This (usage outside forms)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZZCXnNAOqqU)

segments.source_content: Arguably one of the most used and most important React Native libraries out there is React Navigation. The current major version (6) was introduced roughly three years ago, and now it seems weâ€™re getting closer to the next major release. With v7 (currently in alpha), React Navigation is (re-)introducing a static API, which lets you define screens from an object configuration. This allows type inference (if youâ€™ve ever created types for a dynamic React Navigation tree you know what that relieves you of) and also makes deep linking config easier (or partly automatic, even).

translations.fr: Sans doute l'une des bibliothÃ¨ques React Native les plus utilisÃ©es et les plus importantes est React Navigation. La version majeure actuelle (6) a Ã©tÃ© introduite il y a environ trois ans, et il semble maintenant que nous nous rapprochions de la prochaine version majeure. Avec la v7 (actuellement en alpha), React Navigation rÃ©introduit une API statique, qui vous permet de dÃ©finir les Ã©crans Ã  partir d'une configuration objet. Cela permet l'infÃ©rence de types (si vous avez dÃ©jÃ  crÃ©Ã© des types pour un arbre React Navigation dynamique, vous savez Ã  quoi cela vous soulage) et rend Ã©galement la configuration des liens profonds plus facile (voire partiellement automatique).
translations.en: Sans doute l'une des bibliothÃ¨ques React Native les plus utilisÃ©es et importantes, React Navigation voit sa version majeure actuelle (6) introduite il y a environ trois ans. Avec la v7 (actuellement en alpha), React Navigation rÃ©introduit une API statique permettant de dÃ©finir les Ã©crans via une configuration objet. Cela permet l'infÃ©rence de types (si vous avez dÃ©jÃ  crÃ©Ã© des types pour un arbre React Navigation dynamique, vous savez le gain que cela reprÃ©sente) et facilite Ã©galement la configuration des liens profonds (voire la rend partiellement automatique).

- ğŸ“œ [Expo - How to replace App Center and CodePush](https://expo.dev/blog/how-to-replace-app-center-and-codepush): As reported last week, CodePush is shutting down on March 31, 2025.
- ğŸ“œ Two Expo case studies: [Win your March Madness bracket with this Expo app](https://expo.dev/blog/march-madness-expo-app) and [incident.io harnesses the power of native modules and CNG](https://expo.dev/blog/incident-io-harnesses-the-power-of-native-modules-and-cng)
- ğŸ“œ [Rethinking Layout Practices - A minimalistic Stack component that sets the foundation for doing layout well](https://www.reactnative.university/blog/rethinking-layout-practices): Interesting take: Never layout using padding or margin on Text or View components and instead introduce a Stack component (Tamagui does this for example).
- ğŸ“œ [Optimize Your React Native Appâ€™s JavaScript Bundle](https://www.callstack.com/blog/optimize-react-native-apps-javascript-bundle): The title doesnâ€™t give it away, but this is an interesting overview of alternative bundlers for RN. Sadly, all of these still have pretty big trade-offs compared to Metro.
